column2: Programming Fundamentals
MCQs
column3: True/False Questions:
column4: Descriptive Questions:

column2: Which of the following is not a valid data type in most programming languages? a) Integer b) String c) Boolean d) Character
column3: True or False: In programming  a variable can store different data types at different times.
column4: Explain the concept of a variable in programming and provide an example.

column2: What is the data type of the variable "price" if it stores a decimal number? a) Integer b) Float c) String d) Boolean
column3: True or False: Variable names are case-sensitive in most programming languages.
column4: What is the difference between a variable and a constant?

column2: Which of the following variables stores true/false values? a) Integer b) Float c) Boolean d) String
column3: True or False: The value of a variable can be changed during program execution.
column4: How do you declare a variable in most programming languages?

column2: In programming  a variable is: a) A fixed value that cannot be changed b) A container for storing data c) A keyword used for loops d) An error in the code
column3: True or False: A variable must be declared before it can be used.
column4: What is the scope of a variable in programming?

column2: Which of the following is a valid variable name? a) 1count b) total count c) totalCount d) count$
column3: True or False: Variables cannot be used to perform calculations in programming.
column4: What are the common rules for naming variables in programming?

column2: Which control structure is used to execute a block of code repeatedly as long as a condition is true? a) if statement b) switch statement c) for loop d) while loop
column3: True or False: The "else if" statement can be used multiple times in an if-else control structure.
column4: Explain the difference between the "while" loop and the "do-while" loop.

column2: What is the purpose of the "else" statement in an if-else control structure? a) It is used to repeat a block of code. b) It is used to specify multiple conditions. c) It is used to execute a block of code when the condition is false. d) It is used to skip the rest of the code block.
column3: True or False: The do-while loop executes the loop body at least once  even if the condition is false.
column4: What is the purpose of the "switch" statement and how does it work?

column2: In a for loop  what does the "initialization" step do? a) It sets the loop condition. b) It increments the loop counter. c) It initializes the loop variable. d) It defines the loop body.
column3: True or False: A switch statement can be used with both numeric and string expressions.
column4: How is a for loop different from a while loop?

column2: What is the purpose of the "break" statement in a loop? a) It ends the loop and transfers control to the next iteration. b) It skips the rest of the code block and continues with the next iteration. c) It exits the loop and transfers control to the next statement after the loop. d) It restarts the loop from the beginning.
column3: True or False: The "continue" statement is used to skip the rest of the code block and continue with the next iteration of the loop.
column4: Explain the concept of nested control structures with an example.

column2: Which control structure is used to select one of many code blocks to execute based on different conditions? a) if statement b) switch statement c) for loop d) while loop
column3: True or False: An if-else statement can be nested inside another if-else statement.
column4: What are some common mistakes or pitfalls to avoid when using control structures?

column2: What is a function in programming? a) A variable that stores data b) A conditional statement c) A reusable block of code d) An error in the code
column3: True or False: A function can only receive input values but cannot return any output.
column4: Explain the difference between a function parameter and an argument.

column2: What is the purpose of using functions in programming? a) To store data b) To control program flow c) To perform a specific task or calculation d) To print output on the screen
column3: True or False: The main() function is required in all programming languages.
column4: How do you define a function in most programming languages?

column2: Which of the following is not a benefit of using functions? a) Code reusability b) Modularity c) Increased code complexity d) Improved code organization
column3: True or False: A function can be called from within another function.
column4: What is the difference between the "return" statement and the "print" statement?

column2: What is a parameter in a function? a) The value returned by the function b) The name given to a function c) A value passed into a function d) A condition that determines function execution
column3: True or False: A function can have multiple return statements.
column4: What is the concept of a "void" function?

column2: What is the difference between a function definitionand a function call? a) A function definition is where a function is created and a function call is where it is used.  b) A function definition is where a function is used and a function call is where it is created.  c) A function definition is where a function is modified and a function call is where it is executed.  d) A function definition is where a function is executed and a function call is where it is modified.
column3: True or False: Functions cannot be recursive meaning a function cannot call itself.
column4: How can you pass an array as a parameter to a function?

column2: Object Oriented Programming
MCQs
column3: True/False Questions:
column4: Descriptive Questions:

column2: Which keyword is used to define a class in C++? a) class b) struct c) object d) main
column3: True or False: Objects are instances of classes.
column4: What is a class in C++?

column2: Which access specifier is used to make class members accessible within the class and its derived classes? a) public b) private c) protected d) friend
column3: True or False: A class can have multiple constructors with different parameter lists.
column4: Explain the concept of object-oriented programming.

column2: Which of the following is a correct way to create an object of a class named "Person"? a) object Person b) Person obj c) create Person d) new Person
column3: True or False: In C++
column4: How do you define a member function outside the class declaration?

column2: Which operator is used to access member functions and data members of an object? a) . b) -> c) :: d) :
column3: True or False: Destructors have the same name as the class and are prefixed with a tilde (~).
column4: What is the difference between private and protected and  and public access specifiers in C++?

column2: Which function is automatically called when an object of a class is created? a) initialize() b) main() c) constructor d) destructor
column3: True or False: The default access specifier for members in a class is protected.
column4: What is a constructor in C++?

column2: Which keyword is used to derive a class from a base class in C++? a) derive b) inherit c) extends d) :
column3: True or False: Inheritance allows a class to inherit properties and behaviors from another class.
column4: What is inheritance in C++?

column2: Which type of inheritance allows a derived class to inherit from multiple base classes? a) single inheritance b) multiple inheritance c) hierarchical inheritance d) hybrid inheritance
column3: True or False: A derived class can access private members of its base class.
column4: Explain the types of inheritance supported in C++.

column2: What is the access specifier used when deriving a class privately? a) public b) private c) protected d) friend
column3: True or False: Multiple inheritance allows a class to inherit from multiple derived classes.
column4: What are access specifiers in inheritance?

column2: Which feature of OOP is demonstrated by inheritance? a) encapsulation b) polymorphism c) abstraction d) data hiding
column3: True or False: Constructors and destructors are inherited by derived classes.
column4: What is function overriding in inheritance?

column2: Which function is called automatically by the compiler when an object of a derived class is created? a) constructor b) destructor c) main() d) virtual function
column3: True or False: The derived class is always smaller in size compared to its base class.
column4: How does the virtual keyword impact function behavior in inheritance?

column2: What is polymorphism in C++? a) The ability to create objects from classes b) The process of hiding data within a class c) The ability of an object to take on many forms d) The process of defining multiple constructors for a class
column3: True or False: Polymorphism allows a derived class to inherit from multiple base classes.
column4: What is the difference between compile-time polymorphism and runtime polymorphism?

column2: Which type of polymorphism is achieved through function overloading? a) Compile-time polymorphism b) Runtime polymorphism c) Static polymorphism d) Dynamic polymorphism
column3: True or False: Virtual functions can be implemented in the base class and overridden in derived classes.
column4: Explain the concept of function overloading in C++.

column2: What is the purpose of virtual functions in C++? a) To perform type checking at compile-time b) To allow the creation of abstract classes c) To enable late binding and dynamic method dispatch d) To restrict access to class members
column3: True or False: Polymorphism can be achieved through function overloading and function overriding.
column4: How does function overriding contribute to polymorphism in C++?

column2: Which keyword is used to override a virtual function in a derived class? a) override b) virtual c) super d) polymorphic
column3: True or False: Dynamic polymorphism is resolved at compile-time.
column4: What is an abstract class in C++?

column2: What is the significance of pure virtual functions in C++? a) They cannot be called directly and must be overridden in derived classes b) They can only be called by objects of the base class c) They can be called directly and must be overridden in derived classes d) They can only be called by objects of the derived class
column3: True or False: Abstract classes can be instantiated.
column4: How can you achieve runtime polymorphism in C++?

column2: Which of the following is not a valid data type in C++? a) int b) float c) boolean d) string

column3: True or False: In C++  the "bool" data type can store either "true" or "false" values.

column3: True or False: Variables in C++ must be declared before they can be used.
column4: What is the purpose of the "sizeof" operator in C++?

column2: What is the range of the "short" data type in C++? a) -128 to 127 b) 0 to 255 c) -32768 to 32767 d) -2147483648 to 2147483647
column3: True or False: The "unsigned" keyword is used to declare signed variables in C++.

column2: Which data type can store decimal numbers with a higher precision compared to "float" in C++? a) double b) long double c) real d) decimal
column3: True or False: The "long" data type in C++ is guaranteed to be larger than the "int" data type.
column4: What is the range of values that can be stored in a "char" data type in C++?

column2: Which control structure allows a block of code to be executed repeatedly as long as a condition is true? a) if statement b) switch statement c) for loop d) while loop
column3: True or False: The "switch" statement in C++ can only be used with integer and character types.

column2: Which loop structure is guaranteed to execute at least once regardless of the condition? a) for loop b) while loop c) do-while loop d) nested loop
column3: True or False: The "for" loop in C++ is similar to the "while" loop  but with a different syntax.
column4: How does the "for" loop differ from the "while" loop in C++?

column2: How many times will the following code segment be executed? int i = 1 while (i <= 5) { cout << i << " " i += 2 } a) 1 time b) 2 times c) 3 times d) 5 times
column3: True or False: The "break" statement in C++ is used to exit the loop and continue with the next iteration.
column4: What is the purpose of the "switch" statement in C++?

column2: Which control structure allows a program to selectively execute different blocks of code based on different conditions? a) if statement b) for loop c) switch statement d) do-while loop
column3: True or False: A "nested loop" refers to a loop inside another loop in C++.
column4: How can you exit a loop prematurely in C++?

column2: What will be the output of the following code? int x = 10 if (x > 5) { cout << "Hello" } else { cout << "World" } a) Hello b) World c) Hello World d) No output
column3: TTrue or False: he condition in the "do-while" loop is checked before executing the loop body.
column4: What is the difference between the "do-while" loop and the "while" loop in C++?

column2: Which keyword is used to define a function in C++? a) func b) def c) fun d) void
column3: True or False: A function can be called recursively meaning it calls itself.
column4: What is a function in C++?

column2: What is the purpose of a return type in a function declaration? a) It specifies the name of the function. b) It indicates the number of parameters the function accepts. c) It specifies the data type of the value returned by the function. d) It determines the visibility of the function.
column3: True or False: A function can have multiple return statements within its body.
column4: How do you declare a function in C++?

column2: Which of the following is true about function overloading in C++? a) Two functions can have the same name but different return types. b) Two functions can have the same name and same parameter types but different return types. c) Two functions can have the same name and same return type but different parameter types. d) Function overloading is not allowed in C++.
column3: True or False: Parameters in a function declaration are optional.
column4: What is function overloading in C++?

column2: Which of the following is the correct way to pass an array to a function in C++? a) Pass by value b) Pass by reference c) Pass by pointer d) Pass by constant reference
column3: True or False: Functions can only return a single value in C++.
column4: How can you pass an array to a function in C++?

column2: What is the purpose of a function prototype in C++? a) It defines the body of the function. b) It declares the existence and signature of a function before it is defined. c) It specifies the return type of the function. d) It determines the visibility of the function.
column3: True or False: A function can modify the original values of its arguments if they are passed by reference.
column4: What is the difference between a function declaration and a function definition in C++?

column2: Data Structures
MCQs
column3: True/False Questions:
column4: Descriptive Questions:

column2: Which of the following statements about linked lists is true? a) Linked lists provide constant time access to any element. b) Linked lists have a fixed size determined at compile time. c) Linked lists can easily insert or delete elements at any position. d) Linked lists can only be traversed in a forward direction.
column3: True or False: In a singly linked list traversal from the last element to the first element is efficient.
column4: What is a linked list?

column2: In a singly linked list which operation has a time complexity of O(1)? a) Insertion at the beginning. b) Insertion at the end. c) Deletion from the beginning. d) Deletion from the end.
column3: True or False: Circular linked lists can be implemented using either singly linked lists or doubly linked lists.
column4: What are the advantages of using linked lists over arrays?

column2: Which of the following statements about doubly linked lists is true? a) Doubly linked lists require less memory compared to singly linked lists. b) Doubly linked lists cannot be traversed in a backward direction. c) Doubly linked lists have a higher time complexity for insertion and deletion compared to singly linked lists. d) Doubly linked lists have better cache locality compared to singly linked lists.
column3: True or False: Linked lists are a dynamic data structure that can grow or shrink in size during program execution.
column4: What is a singly linked list?

column2: The process of combining two or more linked lists into a single list is called: a) Merging. b) Concatenation. c) Reversal. d) Partitioning.
column3: True or False: Linked lists consume less memory compared to arrays for storing the same amount of data.
column4: What is a doubly linked list?

column2: Which of the following data structures can be used to implement a stack using a linked list? a) Singly linked list. b) Doubly linked list. c) Circular linked list. d) All of the above.
column3: True or False: Deleting an element from a doubly linked list requires updating the next and previous pointers of the adjacent nodes.
column4: What is the time complexity for inserting an element at the end of a singly linked list?

column2: In a binary tree  each node can have a maximum of how many children? a) 1 b) 2 c) 3 d) There is no maximum limit
column3: True or False: In a binary tree the left subtree of a node contains smaller values and the right subtree contains larger values.
column4: What is a binary tree?

column2: Which traversal visits the left subtree then the root and finally the right subtree? a) Preorder traversal b) Inorder traversal c) Postorder traversal d) Level order traversal
column3: True or False: Binary trees can be empty meaning they contain no nodes.
column4: What is the difference between a binary tree and a binary search tree?

column2: Which of the following statements about binary trees is true? a) Binary trees always have an equal number of left and right children. b) Binary trees are a type of balanced tree. c) Binary trees can have any number of children per node. d) Binary trees can have at most two children per node.
column3: True or False: The height of a binary tree is always equal to the number of nodes in the tree.
column4: What is the height of a binary tree?

column2: The height of a binary tree with n nodes is at most: a) n b) log(n) c) n - 1 d) 2^n
column3: True or False: Binary trees can be traversed in multiple ways including preorder and inorder and postorder.
column4: How is a binary tree represented in memory?

column2: Which operation is used to remove a node from a binary search tree? a) Rotate b) Split c) Delete d) Extract
column3: True or False: A binary tree can have a node with only a right child but no left child.
column4: What is the time complexity for searching a value in a binary search tree?

column2: Which sorting algorithm has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2)? a) Bubble Sort b) Merge Sort c) Quick Sort d) Insertion Sort
column3: True or False: Merge Sort is an example of a comparison-based sorting algorithm.
column4: What is a sorting algorithm?

column2: Which sorting algorithm guarantees a worst-case time complexity of O(n log n)? a) Selection Sort b) Radix Sort c) Heap Sort d) Bubble Sort
column3: True or False: Radix Sort is suitable for sorting arrays with both positive and negative integers.
column4: What is the time complexity of a sorting algorithm?

column2: Which sorting algorithm is known for its stability meaning it preserves the relative order of equal elements? a) Quick Sort b) Insertion Sort c) Selection Sort d) Merge Sort
column3: True or False: Quick Sort is an in-place sorting algorithm.
column4: What is the difference between comparison-based and non-comparison-based sorting algorithms?

column2: The best-case time complexity of Bubble Sort is: a) O(n) b) O(n^2) c) O(log n) d) O(n log n)
column3: True or False: Bubble Sort is an efficient sorting algorithm for large arrays.
column4: Name a stable sorting algorithm.

column2: Which sorting algorithm works by repeatedly finding the minimum element from the unsorted portion of the array and placing it at the beginning? a) Bubble Sort b) Quick Sort c) Selection Sort d) Insertion Sort
column3: True or False: Insertion Sort is a stable sorting algorithm.
column4: What is the main advantage of using quicksort over other sorting algorithms?

column2: Analysis of Algorithms
MCQs
column3: True/False Questions:
column4: Descriptive Questions:

column2: Which of the following is true about asymptotic analysis? a) It gives an exact measurement of algorithmic efficiency b) It ignores small input sizes c) It is only applicable to recursive algorithms d) It only considers the worst-case scenario
column3: True or False: Asymptotic analysis only considers the worst-case scenario.
column4: What is asymptotic analysis?

column2: Which of the following notation represents a function that grows faster than logarithmic but slower than exponential? a) O(1) b) O(log n) c) O(n) d) O(2^n)
column3: True or False: Big-O notation represents the exact growth rate of a function.
column4: What is Big-O notation?

column2: Which of the following is the correct definition of Big-O notation? a) It represents the lower bound of the growth rate of a function b) It represents the upper bound of the growth rate of a function c) It represents the exact growth rate of a function d) It represents the average growth rate of a function
column3: True or False: Theta notation represents the lower bound of the growth rate of a function.
column4: What is the difference between O(1) and O(n)?

column2: Which of the following is not a valid asymptotic notation? a) O(1) b) O(n!) c) O(log n) d) O(n^2)
column3: True or False: Asymptotic analysis is only applicable to recursive algorithms.
column4: What is the purpose of asymptotic analysis?

column2: Which of the following is true about Theta notation? a) It represents the upper bound of the growth rate of a function b) It represents the lower bound of the growth rate of a function c) It represents both the upper and lower bounds of the growth rate of a function d) It represents the exact growth rate of a function
column3: True or False: Asymptotic analysis is a way to measure the efficiency of an algorithm.
column4: What is the worst-case time complexity of an algorithm?

column2: Which of the following sorting algorithms has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2)? a) Merge sort b) Quick sort c) Heap sort d) Insertion sort
column3: True or False: Bubble sort has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2).
column4: What is a sorting algorithm?

column2: Which of the following sorting algorithms is based on the divide-and-conquer strategy? a) Bubble sort b) Selection sort c) Insertion sort d) Merge sort
column3: True or False: Quick sort is a stable sorting algorithm.
column4: Explain the concept of in-place sorting.

column2: Which of the following sorting algorithms has a best-case time complexity of O(n)? a) Quick sort b) Bubble sort c) Insertion sort d) Heap sort
column3: True or False: Selection sort is an in-place sorting algorithm.
column4: What is the time complexity of bubble sort?

column2: Which of the following sorting algorithms guarantees a stable sort? a) Quick sort b) Selection sort c) Merge sort d) Radix sort
column3: True or False: Merge sort is based on the divide-and-conquer strategy.
column4: What is the main advantage of merge sort over other sorting algorithms?

column2: Which of the following sorting algorithms is not an in-place sorting algorithm? a) Bubble sort b) Heap sort c) Insertion sort d) Shell sort
column3: True or False: Radix sort has a worst-case time complexity of O(nlogn).
column4: How does quick sort work?

column2: Which algorithm is used to find the shortest path between two vertices in a weighted graph? a) Breadth-First Search (BFS) b) Depth-First Search (DFS) c) Dijkstra's algorithm d) Prim's algorithm
column3: True or False: Breadth-First Search (BFS) can be used to find the shortest path in an unweighted graph.
column4: What is a graph algorithm?

column2: Which algorithm is used to find the minimum spanning tree of a weighted graph? a) Breadth-First Search (BFS) b) Depth-First Search (DFS) c) Dijkstra's algorithm d) Prim's algorithm
column3: True or False: Depth-First Search (DFS) can be used to detect cycles in a graph.
column4: Explain the concept of breadth-first search (BFS).

column2: Which algorithm is used to detect cycles in a graph? a) Breadth-First Search (BFS) b) Depth-First Search (DFS) c) Dijkstra's algorithm d) Prim's algorithm
column3: True or False: Dijkstra's algorithm can be used to find the minimum spanning tree of a weighted graph.
column4: What is the time complexity of Dijkstra's algorithm?

column2: Which algorithm is used to find the strongly connected components in a directed graph? a) Breadth-First Search (BFS) b) Depth-First Search (DFS) c) Dijkstra's algorithm d) Prim's algorithm
column3: True or False: Prim's algorithm can be used to find the shortest path between two vertices in a weighted graph.
column4: What is the minimum spanning tree of a graph?

column2: Which algorithm is used to find the topological ordering of vertices in a directed acyclic graph (DAG)? a) Breadth-First Search (BFS) b) Depth-First Search (DFS) c) Dijkstra's algorithm d) Prim's algorithm
column3: True or False: Depth-First Search (DFS) can be used to find the topological ordering of vertices in a directed acyclic graph (DAG).
column4: What is the difference between DFS and BFS?
